chat_history.content:
<document>
<title>List of Stranger Things episodes</title>
<fragment>
Science fiction TV program list

*Stranger Things* is an American science fiction fantasy horror drama television series created by the Duffer Brothers that is streaming on Netflix. The brothers serve as showrunners and are executive producers along with Shawn Levy and Dan Cohen. The first season of the series was released on Netflix on July 15, 2016,[1] with the second, third, and fourth seasons following in October 2017, July 2019, and May and July 2022, respectively.[2][3][4]


As of July 1, 2022,[update] 34 episodes of *Stranger Things* have been released, concluding the fourth season. In February 2022, Netflix renewed the series for a fifth and final season.[5]




## Series overview[edit]


| Season | Episodes | Originally released |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 1 | 8 | July 15, 2016 (2016-07-15) |
| 2 | 9 | October 27, 2017 (2017-10-27) |
| 3 | 8 | July 4, 2019 (2019-07-04) |
| 4 | 9 | 7 | May 27, 2022 (2022-05-27) |
| 2 | July 1, 2022 (2022-07-01) |
| 5 | 8[6] | TBA |

## Episodes[edit]


</fragment>
<fragment>

1. **^** de Moraes, Lisa (January 17, 2016). "Netflix Unveils Premiere Dates For 'Orange Is The New Black,' 'The Get Down,' 'Flaked' And Others". *Deadline Hollywood*. Archived from the original on July 16, 2019. Retrieved January 2, 2017.
2. **^** Harnick, Chris (July 11, 2017). "Stranger Things Season 2 Premiere Date, Huge Monster Threat Revealed". *E! Online*. Archived from the original on July 11, 2017. Retrieved July 11, 2017.
3. **^** Wigler, Josh (December 31, 2018). "Netflix Reveals 'Stranger Things' Season 3 Premiere Date". *The Hollywood Reporter*. Archived from the original on January 1, 2019. Retrieved January 1, 2019.
4. **^** Campione, Katie (February 17, 2022). "'Stranger Things' Season 4 Gets a Premiere Date, But New Season Will Be Split in Half". *The Wrap*. Archived from the original on February 17, 2022. Retrieved February 17, 2022.

</fragment>

chat_history.content:
<document>
<title>List of 13 Reasons Why episodes</title>
<fragment>
*13 Reasons Why* is an American teen drama television series developed for Netflix by Brian Yorkey, based on the 2007 novel *Thirteen Reasons Why* by Jay Asher.[1] During the course of the series, 49 episodes of *13 Reasons Why* were released over four seasons, between March 31, 2017, and June 5, 2020.




## Series overview[edit]


| Season | Episodes | Originally released |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 1 | 13 | March 31, 2017 (2017-03-31) |
| 2 | 13 | May 18, 2018 (2018-05-18) |
| 3 | 13 | August 23, 2019 (2019-08-23) |
| 4 | 10 | June 5, 2020 (2020-06-05) |

## Episodes[edit]


### Season 1 (2017)[edit]




</fragment>
<fragment>

| No.overall | No. inseason | Title | Directed by | Written by | Original release date |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 40 | 1 | "Winter Break" | Russell Mulcahy | Brian Yorkey | June 5, 2020 (2020-06-05) |

</fragment>
<fragment>

| No.overall | No. inseason | Title | Directed by | Written by | Original release date |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 1 | 1 | "Tape 1, Side A" | Tom McCarthy | *Teleplay by* : Brian Yorkey | March 31, 2017 (2017-03-31) |

</fragment>
<fragment>

| No.overall | No. inseason | Title | Directed by | Written by | Original release date |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 14 | 1 | "The First Polaroid" | Gregg Araki | Brian Yorkey | May 18, 2018 (2018-05-18) |
| Five months after the events of the first season, Hannah's trial moves to court. Tyler is the first to testify in the trial and does so truthfully. Skye and Clay are dating, but Clay starts to have hallucinations of Hannah. Mr. Porter confronts Bryce in the bathroom about raping Hannah. Jessica returns to school, as does Alex who survived his suicide attempt but has lost much of his memory from before it, including the contents of Hannah's tapes. Tony is given the note Hannah left him the night she died and is later seen burning it. A Polaroid was left in Clay's locker, with a note saying "Hannah wasn't the only one".



---


</fragment>
<fragment>

| No.overall | No. inseason | Title | Directed by | Written by | Original release date |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 27 | 1 | "Yeah. I'm the New Girl" | Michael Morris | Brian Yorkey | August 23, 2019 (2019-08-23) |
| *Flashbacks*: On the night of the Spring Fling, Clay and Tony help Tyler dispose of the weapons while Justin, Zach, and Cyrus assist with the police. The next day, Clay organizes a schedule for the group to support Tyler's recovery, except for Zach who believes Tyler is dangerous. During school, Clay shows a new student, Ani Achola, around and introduces her to his friends. Ani suggests that Jessica run for class president, leading to a friendship. Bryce moves in with his mother after his father leaves town and sells their house.

</fragment>
<fragment>
Afterwards, the surviving tape recipients bury Hannah's tapes while Jessica states that Bryce, despite his cruelty, played a part in uniting them. Clay finds Justin's college admissions essay, wherein Justin considered Clay his brother and a positive influence in his life. Clay decides to continue therapy and leaves with Tony on a road trip.
 |


## References[edit]


1. **^** Jaafar, Ali (October 29, 2015). "Netflix Gives Selena Gomez's '13 Reasons Why' Straight-To-Series Order". *Deadline Hollywood*. Archived from the original on October 30, 2015. Retrieved October 29, 2016.
2. **^** Goldberg, Lesley (July 15, 2019). "Netflix Alters Graphic '13 Reasons Why' Suicide Scene After Controversy". *The Hollywood Reporter*. Retrieved July 17, 2019.

chat_history.content:
<document>
<title>List of Money Heist episodes</title>
<fragment>

In late 2017, Netflix acquired the global streaming rights for the series,[1] and re-cut the original 15 episodes into 22.[2] Netflix officially renewed the series for a third part in 2018,[3] which premiered on 19 July 2019.[4] A fourth part was released on 3 April 2020.[5] A documentary involving the producers and cast premiered on Netflix the same day, titled *Money Heist: The Phenomenon*.[6][7] In July 2020, Netflix renewed the show for a fifth and final part,[8] which were released in two five-episode volumes on 3 September and 3 December 2021, respectively.[9] Similar to *Money Heist: The Phenomenon*, a two-part documentary involving the producers and cast premiered on Netflix the same day, titled *Money Heist: From Tokyo to Berlin*.[10]


During the course of the series, 41 episodes of *Money Heist[a]* were released over five parts, between 2 May 2017 and 3 December 2021.[b]




## Series overview[edit]


</fragment>
<fragment>

Overview of *Money Heist* seasons| Part[b] | Season[b] | Episodes | Originally released |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| First released | Last released | Network |
| 1 | 1 | 9[a] | 2 May 2017 (2017-05-02) | 27 June 2017 (2017-06-27) | Antena 3 |
| 2 | 6[a] | 16 October 2017 (2017-10-16) | 23 November 2017 (2017-11-23) |
| 3 | 2 | 8 | 19 July 2019 (2019-07-19) | Netflix |
| 4 | 8 | 3 April 2020 (2020-04-03) |
| 5 | 3 | 10 | 5 | 3 September 2021 (2021-09-03) |
| 5 | 3 December 2021 (2021-12-03) |

## Episodes[edit]


### Part 1 (2017)[edit]




</fragment>
<fragment>

1. ^ ***a*** ***b*** ***c*** Part 1 was re-cut and released as 13 episodes on 20 December 2017 on Netflix, and Part 2 was re-cut and released as 9 episodes on 6 April 2018 on Netflix. See *Money Heist* § Netflix acquisition.
2. ^ ***a*** ***b*** ***c*** Some publications refer to "part" as "season."[11][12]

## References[edit]


</fragment>
<fragment>

1. **^** "It's back! Netflix to screen Casa de Papel aka Money Heist Series 3 in July". thelocal.es. 2 April 2019. Archived from the original on 14 April 2019. Retrieved 11 August 2019.
2. **^** Marcos, Natalia (29 March 2018). "Por qué 'La casa de papel' ha sido un inesperado éxito internacional". *El País* (in Spanish). Archived from the original on 2 July 2019. Retrieved 18 August 2019.
3. **^** Tartaglione, Nancy (18 April 2018). "'Money Heist': Netflix Confirms Season 3 Of Spanish-Language Phenomenon". *Deadline Hollywood*. Archived from the original on 18 April 2018. Retrieved 18 April 2018.
4. **^** ""La casa de papel", temporada 4: fecha de estreno en Netflix, qué pasará, actores, personajes, misterios y teorías". elcomercio.pe. 10 August 2019. Archived from the original on 21 July 2019. Retrieved 10 August 2019.
5. **^** "'Money Heist' Season 4 Coming to Netflix in April 2020". *iTech Hacks*. 8 December 2019.

</fragment>
</document>
chat_history.name: search

chat_history.content:
Here are the top 5 most-watched Netflix series in their first 28 days along with the number of episodes each series has:

1. **Squid Game: Season 1**
   - **Genre:** Survival drama
   - **Hours watched:** 1,650.45 million
   - **Episodes:** 9

2. **Stranger Things: Season 4**
   - **Genre:** Science fiction/Horror
   - **Hours watched:** 1,352.09 million
   - **Episodes:** 9

3. **Wednesday: Season 1**
   - **Genre:** Supernatural horror
   - **Hours watched:** 1,237.15 million
   - **Episodes:** 8

4. **Dahmer – Monster: The Jeffrey Dahmer Story: Limited Series**
   - **Genre:** Horror drama
   - **Hours watched:** 856.22 million
   - **Episodes:** 10

5. **Money Heist: Part 5**
   - **Genre:** Heist/Crime drama
   - **Hours watched:** 792.23 million
   - **Episodes:** 10

### Additional Information on Episode Counts:
- **Stranger Things** has a total of 34 episodes across its four released seasons.
- **13 Reasons Why** has a total of 49 episodes across its four seasons.
- **Money Heist** has a total of 41 episodes across its five parts.

For more detailed information on each series, you can refer to their respective episode lists on Wikipedia.

functions.name: search
functions.desc: Search Wikipedia for an article with the given title, and get its content. If no such article is found, return similar article names.
